course.subject: COMP
course.name: Programming with C++
course.description: This course covers programming and data structures using C++. In addition to basic programming concepts such as variables and control statements, students will learn about arrays, pointers, dynamic data allocation, linked lists, stacks, queues, binary trees, recursion, and the basics of object oriented programming.
course.prerequisites: COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P OR COMP 1022Q (prior to 2020-21) OR ISOM 3230

reviews.author: L.K.
reviews.title: Good Lecture note + Good Instructors = Good Course
reviews.comment_content:
See attached “Lecture Notes.png”
Or you may go to the course website:
https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

▽ Details

Part 1: Basics and Controls
Part 2: Function (Introduction)
Part 3: Array
Part 4: Recursion

Part 5: Scope
Part 6: Function III:
  - Function declaration
  - Function overloading
  - Default Function Argument

Part 7: Separate Compilation
Part 8: C++ Structure

Part 9: Pointers (Intro)
  - lvalue & rvalue
  - dereference a pointer
  - "const" in pointers initialization
  - Array as (constant) pointers

Part 10: Pointers (Usage)
  - Dynamic allocations (on Heap)
  - Problems on dynamic objects:
     ! Dangling pointer
     ! Memory leak
  - Linked List (LL)
  - LL + Binary Tree
  - Dynamic 1D and 2D array

Part 11: C++ Class (Intro)
  - Class == Struct with its own functions
  - keywords "public" and "private"
  - Constructors
     Trigger when a new object is created
  - Destructor
     Need when the object has pointers
  - Accessor
     Always followed by "const"
     Should NOT modify its data members
  - Mutator
     Opposite to accessors
  - Scope operator
     Syntax: <class_name>::
     Use to separate global function and
     member functions (Class scope)

Part 12: Stack and Queue
  - Stack: Last In First Out (LIFO)
  - Queue: First In First Out (FIFO)
  - Stack & Queue + Class
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

You may also download "confusion.pdf"
I listed out some of my confusion
when studying in this semester.

This will be divided into several parts:
confusion_1: Part 1-4 (Finished)
confusion_2: Part 5-6 (Finished)
confusion_3: Part 7-8 (In progress)
...and more

Hope this gives some help :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The best thing in this course:
You can join any lecture that you like,
regardless of your enrolled section.

For me, I join both
Gary and Chatzopoulos's lectures.

Simple comments:
Gary → Build up a basic understanding
Chatzopoulos → Gives lots of practices

In my view,
they are both great instructors.
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

Gary给我的感觉有点像马云其实 XD
有时候上课滔滔不绝讲了十分钟，
总结起来就简单一句话：
「多练就会了」

而且前期他是在PDF上手写的，
时常遇到些问题，浪费了不少时间。

不过这并不妨碍我吹Gary，
他在讲解指针的时候特别的用心。

通过前期的教训，
后期的Gary每次上课都是
左半屏展示Notes，右半屏开白板。

然后在白板上一步一步地
画出指针的走向、应用。

真的很感谢Gary，
在指针上教的那么详细，
不然我期末很可能就死在指针上了。
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

Chatzopoulos真的是希腊人么……
我看着长得跟中东人似的（
（以下简称Chat）

在这个学期，
Gary的课堂是周一 + 周三（上午）
Chat的课堂是周三 + 周五（下午）

所以我每周都是刚上完Gary的课，
紧接着就是上Chat的课。

Chat平常讲课的节奏略快，
不过我此前听过Gary讲了一轮了，
所以对我来说听Chat的课就是在温书。

一般他会在课堂开头先整几个问题，
让我们用Zoom Poll（匿名投票）回答。

不论是匿名投票还是课堂讲解，
他的课堂都特别适合用来温书。

我也特别感谢Chat，
有些问题精准抓住了考点，
使我得以在期末避免犯低级错误。

总之Gary和Chatzopoulos的课
都有着不同的优点和特色。
本人强推这两位的课。
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

# Updated on 2022/04/09 #

焯！Chat跳槽了，亏我写了这么多。

As I know, Chatzopoulos is currently
teaching in other university. So...
This comment is useless now >.<

For the self-note, I'm not satisfied with
the existing notes and I'll rewrite them :)

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy
if your programming experience only
comes from course COMP1021 / 1022q.

---- 1. Lab ----

Some Labs are NOT easy.
(Especially for Lab 7 - 10)

Do recommend leaving at least one day
to finish the tasks in the lab.

---- 2. Programming Assignment ----

Tip 1:
Check the Assignment page regularly
to see if there are any updates.

Tip 2:
Always go to Piazza and ask
if you need more clarifications!

Tip 3:
Leave at least three days
to finish all the tasks in the assignment.
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

压力挺大的其实……
本人进这个课程之前完全没碰过C++

每次做Lab和PA都要花掉不少时间，
每周都要花将近6小时看两位教授讲解。

说实话这门课绝对值四学分。

你不但要了解讲课的大致内容，
还要钻研Notes里的每一个细节，
不然考试问到了你很可能就中招了。

而且说真心话，
有些考题简直就是脱离实际，
谁写代码天天塞堆foo和bar的……

这学期期末有一题在for loop里塞递归，
就是在恶心人，谁会这么写代码啊！

总之一句，放平心态，用心学。
Workload固然大，但也只能认了。

最后奉劝各位：
如果这不是你的必修课，慎入……
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

这Grade着实吓到我了……

考试考完我感觉最多B+（期末太难了）
出成绩感觉最多A-（因为PA1炸了）
结果出来是A

可能这就是人生吧.jpg

这门课好不好grade我真的不好说。
但就个人而言拿A还是挺不容易的。

尤其是期末的第一部分，
一来就是链表加二叉树，
差点把我心态整崩了。

还好接下来两个相比第一个都不算太难。

所以考试要放平心态考，
千万不要因为前面炸了就失去信心。

最后愿各位能把这门课当做一种享受。
毕竟不论考试，这门课从教材到教授，
质量都没的说。

如果你喜欢COMP1021的话，
可以考虑来这科试试。

不过你要做好心里准备：
递归、指针、链表、二叉树……
后期尽是些对新人不友好的东西。

但你还偏偏要熟练地运用这些东西，
因为这些东西期末考必出！
而且必出大题！

所以不是真心喜欢COMP1021的慎入，
因为这门课比COMP1021难得多！

感谢你能看到这里，
也希望这个评论会对你有所帮助。

reviews.author: LuckyTiger
reviews.title: Highly biased and critical review sorry
reviews.comment_content:
Sorry, but I am going to be highly biased and leave a critical review here, because a lot of reviews here make it seem like it's a pretty normal course. However, I am going to speak from the perspective of an average student who got a B in COMP1021 and had no prior experience in C++ before this course. I also have a victim mindset from this course.

This semester they didn't go through in detail the 'basic' lecture notes because apparently, people were complaining that it was apparently too boring. If I remember correctly, they told us to self-read these lecture notes one at a time before each next lecture and skimmed through during lecture time.

http://2011video.cse.ust.hk/videos/list.html

People may question why I went through these videos, but the lecture notes are almost the same and it's from about 10 years ago. 10 years ago Prof Mak took 5+ hours of quality lecture time to introduce C++ while these instructors told us to read it. I guess I am being dramatic because these beginner materials are not hard at all and they did go through it briefly. Oh well, but there's more shit to self-study later on.

The other lecture topics, aside from those in the link

Problems for Basics and Control
Function I
Array
Function II: Recursion
Scope
Function III: Miscellaneous
Separate Compilation
Struct

Pointer
A YouTube video single-handedly made me understand linked list, a sub-topic of this pointer topic.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o5wJkJJpKtM&ab_channel=PaulProgramming

C++ Class
Stack & Queue

Self Study Topics ( for one lab ) ( not tested in exam )
File I/O
String

For each had optional tutorials.
For me I attended both simultaneously because of time management problems, but they weren't that helpful either. But I don't know, the information given in the lecture notes were not that helpful for the lab either.
reviews.comment_teaching:
To be honest, Professor Li is may be passionate. If you think about some instructors, they are indeed capable enough to transmit this curiosity and passion to students. My opinion: Professor Li unfortunately did not have this effect on me.

An immense number of times in lectures, she would go on and on about some part. Her monologues were detailed, but not concise. One thing that would tremendously improve her lecture is live speech-to-text conversion because my attention span could not remember the run-on sentences that she articulated with. She does have a plethora of knowledge to share.

A fact: at the last class, there were less than 10 students in the face-to-face lectures. Around 15 students on zoom. And I still wonder to this day how the were the other 65 students were doing.

I honestly did not know how to attend her lectures for the first half of the semester. After continuous effort going to lectures with a notebook and pen, seeking to draw some clear points being productive and shit... nearing the end of sem, I just sat and listened to her talk. It was actually much better because I got to at least focus on her words more clearly.

It seems like they are recording the lecture but they are not published. Then what's the point of recording it??
Please, I beg you, please, can you please, could you just make it easier for students to access these  information not just for students who are not in HK if you recorded it please?

An D to the teaching at the end because of the culture that they spread, which is honestly not even about plagiarism but about collaboration. They are so strict with plagiarism that they don't allow you to get explicit help from anyone in this course, which sucks, because I was stuck at certain tasks for days. Collaboration is pretty much discouraged. I mean, truth be told, it didn't really affect me because I had no friends but at the same time, I felt very reluctant to ask for help as I thought the help I would get would not be specific enough or whatever. I felt isolated. My opinion.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading? I don't have anything to say. It's fair, for the ability you show, not necessarily the time you spend. That is sort of true with every course and that's no revelation.

I legit couldn't care any less about the so called competition in this course because the only competition there is, is for those smart people who wanna get A-range. I just wanted to get a B or a C.

Most of the contents of the exam seems to focus on the big, later lectures including pointers, stack/queue, class, struct. Recursion and array are  important too. The broadness of topics is actually not bad.

Realistic stats

Quiz 25/35 Mean: 27 or 28
Finals 26/100, mean: 49/100 or something.

Assignments
PA1 88/100, mean 88/100
PA2 59/100, mean 71/100
PA3 88/100, mean 84/100

Every semester, they make 1 or 2 of the PA more difficult/easier or whatever. PA2 is harder this year.

Lab
10/10

Grade I got: C

It's not bad actually, I thought I would be given an F after that finals. I don't even know how you would study for finals. For me, I spent 60% of time revising the lecture notes and going through the examples inside and 40% doing 2 past papers so don't do that.
reviews.comment_workload:
I remember in this semester spending like 2 good days trying to do that self-study lab and still not being able to complete it. The main problem with me is that I did not try hard to seek for help so

TIP: Use the piazza when you need it. Go to office hours if you are truly stuck. The first time I got into office hours, the TA was not strict about straight out giving me solution for first task of a lab.

I remember in this semester spending 5 days to do PA2, that seemingly other people writing these reviews can do within 3 days. Yet I could not finish that assignment and I got 59/100. Fact: I went to counselling because of the hopelessness I suffered while doing the PA2. Fact: When I looked at the answer to PA2. I had two thoughts:

1. What is this?
2. I am satisfied because I would never be able to think of such a complicated solution.

TIP: TO be fair, considering you start really early when the PA is given out, like 2-3 days after it's published, maybe you could finish the PA without so much pressure.

reviews.author: asdfasdfasdfasd
reviews.title: 苦中作樂的 COMP2011
reviews.comment_content: 內容講 C++ 基本同好重要嘅 concept. 最緊要溫熟 pointers, binary tree, and linked list.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia 講英文有輕微口音，不過香港人聽落會好習慣。

Cecia 教得好好同詳細，非常願意堂上即時解答大家問題。不過有時唔太難明嘅 concept 佢都會講得耐得濟，例如 new, delete, pointers, pointers arithmetic. 係學渣們的福音 :)

而且落堂後佢都會留低解答曬問題先走，係個非常負責任嘅 professor.

好記得教到 pointers 時，Cecia 用左好多時間係前三十幾頁 ppt 講解，後來因為唔夠時間，兩堂 KO 左百幾頁 ppt. 千其唔好因為佢教得慢而鬆懈呀~~
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab * 10 (40%) + Quiz * 3 (20%) + Final (40%).

Lab 有 2-3 次大 bonus, 4 次細 bonus.

3 次 quiz 都做得麻麻地，分別為：
僅僅 above mean 幾分，貼 mean, 低過 mean :(
不過 quiz 出得簡單，sd 大到嚇死人

Final 83 分，mean 好似 60 左右，算係正常發揮。本身擔心得 B+，後來因為 lab bonus 加分，出乎意料之外地攞左 A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
見仁見智。
我覺得 workload 好大。
頭幾個 lab 好俾心機做，但係又適逢 Pro P EGM AGM, chur 到懷疑人生。

知識量非常多，要放好多時間讀。

如果 aim B range 就非常輕鬆，lab 隨便做，考好 final 就得。
如果 aim A / A+ 就一定要攞 bonus，要擺多好多時間做...

雖然 A+ 左，但係導致其他 course 時間分配唔均衡...

建議溫好 final 好過，lab 呢 d 留翻 d 識用 Qt，識寫 AI 嘅神人攞就好 :')

Lab 最好揾識嘅 friend 一齊做，可以事半功倍。Year 1 自己一個人衝左去讀，又遇到 pk freerider + 上莊狗，次次要 code 時就係 Whatsapp 到狂吠，約時間出黎傾就 dnlm 一日一覆。大佬，上莊唔緊要，問題係唔好次次約出黎都用莊務做擋箭牌。難得終於約到，原來乜 L 都唔識，pointers 係咩點用仲要我教翻轉頭。顧唔掂學業 and 上莊，就自己 drop 緊其中一樣啦... 唔好再出黎害人啦... 黎緊 18-19 Fall 會讀埋 COMP2012, 希望唔會再遇到佢地啦... :'(

reviews.author: yaboi
reviews.title: You will learn C++ but your grades won't reflect it
reviews.comment_content:
1. Intro
2. Basics 1, 2; Control 1, 2:
Basic syntax of C++, program control.
3. Function I:
Function definition, modular programming, passing parameter (PBV and PBR)
4. Array:
1d, 2d, higher dimension arrays, array definition, initialisation, C string (special type of char[])
5. Recursion:
6. Scope
7. Struct
8. Function III
9. Separate-Compilation
10. Pointer
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue

Honestly, everything upto Pointer is pretty easy stuff. Might be my bias since I studied some basic C++ in COMP1029C and by myself over the summer. The content progression is pretty good but I won't lie, you are better off watching one of those 3-4 hour long C++ tutorials over the span of a week or two and you'll learn (almost) everything in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Brian is a decent teacher. He obviously knows what he's teaching very well and will give you the lower level explanation of most C++ functionality if you ask for it.

The lectures are paced quite poorly in my opinion though. I dont know whether to blame him or whoever made this course syllabus but it spends way to long on basic stuff and too little time on complex topics.

I recommend you self-study most of this course because of this awkward pacing. However, if you have never seen C/C++ code then attending a few lectures might be worthwhile.
reviews.comment_grading:
Ok, so my grade isn't out yet but I will edit my review once it is.

To pass this course, it is not sufficient to have your total score greater than or equal to the pass mark. You are also required to obtain a separate pass mark in your exams. That is, to pass, you are required to have
(total score >= X) AND (quiz score * 0.08 + final exam score * 0.46 >= Y).
X and Y will be determined at the end of the semester but we may promise you that:
X will not be greater than 50, and
Y will not be greater than 16.
(It is assumed that all scores in the above formula are scaled to 100 maximum.)

lab exercises:                      10%
programming assignments: 36% (10%, 12%, 14%)
quiz:                               8%
final exam:                           46%

Means:
Labs: around 2.8/3
PAs: 88.2%, 78.8%, 84.9% (acc. to Canvas)
these means were way higher than previous sems but the assignments were quite easy so I understand why.
Quiz: 79.2%
Final: 40%

Me:
Labs, PAs: 100%
Quiz: 79%
Final: 63.5%
Edit: This got me an A.
Little rant: the final was one of the most poorly designed assessment of a student's skills I have ever seen. Maybe I am just a butthurt baby but seriously, this typing code on Canvas (without being able to use Tabs or a separate text editor) is so time consuming. Plus, you have to remember all variable/class/function names otherwise you spend half your time scrolling back and forth from the code in the question and your code box. Many of the questions basically required you to write an algorithm to perform certain actions like shifting all the elements in a 2D array (without any indexing, only pointers) but you have to dry run everything in your head. Like when and where do you ever have to dry run such a complex algorithm in the real world?!??! A programming course shouldn't even have a final exam, but rather, have really hard projects instead.
reviews.comment_workload: Again, I basically knew C++ coming into this course so the weekly labs and the programming assignments were quite easy. The labs maybe took 2 hours at most, usually an hour though. The assignments took a lot longer though. People complained about memory leaks or whatever but they really aren't that big of an issue in my opinion. Use Zinc to test all your submissions and you'll probably get full too. Overall, appropriate for a 4 cr course.

reviews.author: hwleung
reviews.comment_content:
Topics can be found in other reviews, so I am not writing them down here.
The first half of the content is not difficult, recursion is a bit difficult, and talking about pointer and class - catastrophic.

Be aware of even the smallest details in the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching of Miss Chan is good, she is a nice and helpful person.
You can also ask a lot of questions during the lab, about labs or assignments. Unfortunately, they had been cancelled this semester.
reviews.comment_grading:
Disastrous. DO NOT trust anyone saying that the grading is good. NO, it isn't. If you get mean, you get B-/C+.

The SD of exams/assignments is VERY high.
If you got stuck in a question during the exam, you are over.
Assignments get -10% penalties if there is memory leak.
Do self tests (on the course page) before exams. Study previous labs also.
This is a C++ course, so is your final grade (C+).
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite high. At first, labs aren't difficult. Later, it started to get a bit more difficult. The assignments are very difficult. Take days to complete, or even couldn't complete (added assignment 4 because final was cancelled, very difficult).
Do ask them about assignments if you can.

reviews.author: Raiyan
reviews.comment_content:
BOOK used: The textbook is C++ For Everyone, 2nd Edition, Cay S. Horstmann

Pre-requisite: COMP 1021/1022P/1022Q or ISOM 3230. Exclusion: COMP 1003 / COMP 1004.

Topics:
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue
File input / output (not in exam)

Suggested IDE from the course : Eclipse
Software you may need: Valgrind (Learn linux), Terminal



* Pay attention and never leave out the smallest details. Usually, that's what they will test you with at the end.


Lecture notes are deceiving. It only demonstrates basic knowledge.
Do every labs and assignment and understand them well.


Use office hour even ever you can.

This year, the mid term exam was a variation of the assignments

*If you can use Loops then you can also use Recursion. So when you think of a problem, think about it in both the ways also learn to solve it both ways.




*** INFO used from the course website. https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011 ( Need user log in)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Somewhat boring but visiting during office hours are great. Teachers are really helpful and kind.

3 hours of lectures
2 hours of lab excercises
reviews.comment_grading:
There are TWO components that you must pass in order to pass the ENTIRE course.

quiz 5%
lab exercises 10%
programming assignments 24%
midterm exam 25%
final exam 36%

Super competitive, and you are against extremely hardworking students that can get 100 for everything.

Focus on actually understanding the concepts rather than your grades. You ll get higher grades that way.

Compete against yourself, not others. Looking at others will only intimidate you and you ll get bad grades doing that.
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty high, you have something to do every week.

if youre at ust then you can forget about free time if you wanna do great.

Its good tho because it really teaches you the content by doing.

reviews.author: happystar
reviews.title: Competitive and bad grade this semester
reviews.comment_content:
The content is quite useful, and the lecture note is great. With the lecture note and course materials, it is easy to self study.

However, if COMP 2011 is not your required course (e.g. QFIN). Don't choose this. Go for other COMP course. You will thank me after.

if you are CS students like me, unfortunately, this will be your destiny to stay here. Above mean is definitely not enough. Upper quartile may even give you a B+ or B. Please be at least above 1SD in order to get A-. Given all CS students requires 3.7 gpa to enter, getting above 1SD among these good students is something difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia is nice in term of teaching. However, I think you need to pre-read the lecture note before going the lessons, or I chose to skip lessons and learn my own later after midterm.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is worse. I should be above average, but still B only.

PA: full mark
lab: full mark
Quiz: 19/24  mean:14 (around upper quartile)

reviews.comment_content:
It's basically introduction to C. Very little OPP taught. I think this course builds a good foundation for you in understanding basic programming and common pitfalls.

Before the mid-term, we learned the basic stuff.
After the mid-term, we learned pointers, which can take you some time to get used to the syntax. So make sure you pick good lecture notes to read :P.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor seems to be obsessed with the word ABSTRACTION :P. He is a kind-hearted professor, and is willing to answer students' questions after class. But I'm sorry to say, the organization of his lecture notes was a bit fuzzy, and his lectures were unfortunately boring. =[

But on the contrary, the other lecturer Cecia made good notes (y). Also the TAs were really helpful. =D
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not extremely harsh this semester. I think it is possible to attain an A+ (my friend not me) if you are careful and hardworking.

Mid-term: Mean: 63.77; SD: 17.29
Final: Mean 61.7; Median  67; Std  21.4

The paper was tricky at certain places@@! BE CAREFUL! DON'T miss a symbol when reading the code! My only serious programming experience comes from COMP1021, and this course gave me a painful lesson that I should be really alert to traps in COMP exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
It's a 4 credit course, so what do you expect :D ? The workload is fair I guess.

The labs got more and more difficult as you learned more advanced stuff. Some of them took me a heck of a long time to debug or to understand the algorithm. But they are rewarding if you do them seriously. Anyway, if you are already proficient in programming fundamentals, you probably have the skills to clear all the tasks in seconds.

As for the assignments, I took more time on reading the instructions than writing the actual code lol. You gotta be careful in order to fulfill all the requirements man.

If you do the labs with heart, read through the lecture notes, and practice with past papers, I guarantee that you will do great! No worry~

reviews.author: hime
reviews.title: This review is written from perspective of a non-cse student who has little programming knowledge beforehand
reviews.comment_content:
DISCLAIMER: If you are mature in C++ programming before taking this course, this review is not suitable for you as you should be able to master this course easily.

I am a non-CSE student who has little programming background. I took this course for interest and you can expect there are quite a number of students who already have learnt all the content before taking this course.

For the syllabus in details, please see the other recent reviews as I believe they do not change it. Basically it covers all the basics of c++ programming, i.e., array, string, recursion, pointer, class, etc.

It is not hard in the beginning as it is quite straight forward and your should cover those ideas in COMP1XXX. Things start to become harder when it covers recursive function, and the difficulties comes to its maximum at pointer.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia is a passionate lecturer, I can feel that she always tries her best to make everything clear. However, her tone is kind of dull (maybe due to zoom lecture instead of face-to-face) so you may fall asleep in the middle. Overall she is still a good lecturer.
reviews.comment_grading:
Overall Weighting
Lab 10%
Assignment 8, 10, 14, 12%
Final Exam 44%
Trial Run of Final Exam 1%

As I applied P/F for this semester, I don't really care too much about the grading, yet you still need to get a 50% overall AND 35% (35/100) in your final exam in order to pass this course. As far as I know, this course is very competitive so if you really want to get a good grade, you have to get almost full mark in all the assignments as well as exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
In my opinion, the workload of this course is actually normal as a 4-credit course. There is a lab released in every week. However there is no plagiarism checking for labs so you can simply copy the code from your friends or even from online, yet doing it by yourself is still highly recommended.

The programming assignments(PA) is the main workload during the semester, they are significantly more complex than the labs, so you probably need more time to finish them. In general, I highly recommend to start working on it once it is released because I don't think you can use one day to finish the whole PA, especially for the later ones. The first two PAs are not that hard so most people get full marks in them. However, PA3 is really disastrous and mind-blowing, you probably need to spend a lot of time to understand the requirement even you start to code anything for it. PA4 is less difficult than PA3, but it is still hard. Generally speaking , the workload of the PAs is quite high, especially for the last two PAs, you probably need to spend a lot of time in grinding it if you really want to get full mark in all PAs.

P.S. Don't try to copy directly from others for PA, it definitely doesn't work in the way you want.

you will learn the C++ language and coding skills that can be use in other language. You will also learn how to use VS code and command prompt to do things such as compiling your code. In my opinion, these will very useful even outside this courses.
For the programing stuffs, it is just as you expected, sitting in front of a full screen of code. However, if your only coding experience is form COMP 1021, things might be a lot harder then you might think.
reviews.comment_teaching: Great teaching.The slide themselves are aready clear enough for you to learn everything needed. Professors will demonstrate examples during lecture and that helps you understand better. The HW also have clear guidelines for you to follow and it really helps you strengthen the concept you learn in the lecture. I would say the teaching team have done a good job on making these course meterials.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair. If you are good, you will get good grades.
The HW have a lot of test cases, which lets you check your code. So you should be able to confirm you are able to get full marks before you hand it in.
For the exams, it is not that lucky. I kinda don't like how you have to write programes onto a paper where it is nothing like normal coding where you can try to run your code and debug them.
reviews.comment_workload:
authough it has a fairly long lab section, it is only used to check your understanding on the hw online. You just need to ans some question about the hw and you are free to go. The main workload comes from the 3 big assigment. Which is a longer verson of normal hw. It might takes you a lot more time to finish. But there are only 3 of them.
The revision times actually depends on how well you understand things during the lecture. As there are not much you need to remember. If you understand the concept just from the lecture, you won't even need to do revision.

reviews.author: SmokingPuddle58
reviews.title: I learnt something good, but can be better if the grading can be more generous
reviews.comment_content:
C++ syntax, which is quite different from the Python syntax.

But most importantly, the pointers *. Pointers is the main part of the course that they nearly take a month to teach this. Link list is also important under pointer. Please know how to search, delete, insert items.

But throughtout the course, I feel that the most important chapter is recursion. It is in both midterm and final. And 19% of final is about recursion 😶‍🌫️ and little pointers.

You have to know how to use pointers wisely in the final exam. I mean, recursions, linked lists, classes, blablabla are all related to pointers.

Use pointers like how Desmond Brian Cecia use this. Use this wisely and not like Yan Min.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would not rate too much about teaching because I skipped most of the lectures 🫠.

However Cecia is really a nice person. The date of midterm paper checking clashes with my MATH2033 midterm exam. Still Cecia managed to arrange another paper checking session for us.
reviews.comment_grading:
61% of exam which include

25% midterm : From C++ basics up to Scope

and

36% final: Everything excluding binary tree.

5% of a C++ quiz which test the basic syntax of C++ and also your sight. Get yourself a pair of glasses if you need them. Do not mix "," and ";".

3 * 8% PA: PA are not easy for beginners. I spend days and days in doing the PAs. Give yourself more time. Do not do PA few days before deadline. Do not copy others' PA. They can check and the punishment is heavy (For the first time overall 13% of course grade would be deducted).

10% lab: As long as you know the concept lab will not be difficult for you to finish.

According to Cecia (I asked her during final paper checking):
If you get mean you can only get B-/C+ because this is considered as major required course.

Statistics:

Midterm: 63.75 (Median: 55.75)
Final: 53.65 (Median: 38.43)
Quiz: 18/24 (Median: 14)

For 1 PA I only get 96 and 1 lab I only got 2/3 (Forgot to take attendence but only submitted the file) while nearly everyone get full mark in lab and more than half get full in 3 PAs.

Final grade: B

The grading umm is not bad but I think can be better. But considered that I only slept 2 hours before the final exam due to insomnia, I deserve that score.
reviews.comment_workload:
A bit heavy.

As a little potato who seldomly code, I have to spend days in coding for PAs and labs.

Erm but for the final exam I only spend 4 days in revising so I don't think I spend too much time on it. Probably I should spend more time in revising.

reviews.author: bbkiller
reviews.title: 爛grade到爆
reviews.comment_content:
To pass this course, it is not sufficient to have your total score greater than or equal to the pass mark. You are also required to obtain a separate pass mark in your exams. That is, to pass, you are required to have

(total score >= X) AND (quiz score * 0.10 + final exam score * 0.43 >= Y).

X and Y will be determined at the end of the semester but we may promise you that:
X will not be greater than 50, and
Y will not be greater than 16.
Grading policy:
lab exercises 10%
programming assignments 37% (10%, 12%, 15%)
quiz 10%
final exam 43%
CONTENT:
array
pointers and structure (超難，佢教theory野但好小practical 野，好難明）
class
functions
recursion（看似好難，但你明個theory就會做到）

reviews.comment_teaching: Cindy teaches slowly and patiently as she explains everything in detail with flow charts sketched during courses. She is also more than willing to answer questions after class(she once stayed nearly 2hrs behind) or through emails. You may feel the pace is slow in the beginning but as time goes by the content also becomes trickier then you start panicking. May be way too slow for genius coders.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz: 18/24 (mean: 18.24)
Lab: full marks (3 points* 10 labs)
PA1: 100/100 (mean: 79.63)
PA2: 97.3/100 (mean: 86.87)
PA3: 96/100 (mean: 68.71)
Final: 36.5 (mean: 40.28; SD: 21.32; max : 92.5)

Letter Grade: B
Definitely need a few friends to back up you/kindly assist you along the freaking PA writing journey. I tried so hard to debug and poured blood, sweat and tears to complete all tasks. I learned so much and actually enjoyed the process nevertheless.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. The labs weren't too demanding but it comes every week so be sure to manage your time wisely.

2. As for PAs, approximately 1 day for problem reading/understanding, and coming up with some brief ideas of solution in your mind.  Actual implementation takes roughly 2-4 days, debugging is usually the most painful part(crying internally). Do start early so you will have time for revision. We had a lot of recursion problems this semester and "thinking recursively" is the key to tackle the problem.

3. Final: Though I got a shitty grade but I really did try HARD for exam prep...remember to finish all the past papers and be familiar with all the ppt contents! Just try to fully understand how all the concepts work and remember it, I mean by being able to type the whole structure down from scratch. You may cry yourself to sleep after the final since it's way too damn hard but you'll be fine if you tried hard enough, trust me.

4. General advice: First, practice typing all the coding examples on the ppts by yourself, merely understanding is far from enough. Second, when you feel like dying and really cannot compose shit then just go to Piazza to ask for help or ask that kind friend of yours to give you some feedback/support. Just never give up and believe you can surely do this, you can definitely defeat COMP2011. Good luck!!

reviews.author: Trin
reviews.title: If you are ~Mean, then you are C+... If you are not (super) passionate about programming, you may give this a miss.
reviews.comment_content:
Nearly all the C++ Basic, but some important but harder ones are left to COMP2012.

The coverage of topics:
Topics:
1.  C++ Basics
2. Control Flow
3. Basics 2
4. Control 2
5. Function 1
6. Array
7. Function 2 Recursion
8. Scope
9. Struct
10. Function 3 Miscellaneous
11. Separate Compilation
12. Pointer
13. C++ Class
14. Stack and Queue

Intended learning outcomes:
1. Use common software tools to develop and debug a program written in an OOP language. : Use an IDE such as VS Code proficiently to write, compile, run, and debug a C++ program consisting of one or many source files.
2. Write a short program to solve a simple problem in an OOP language.: Construct a solution to a written problem by writing a complete C++ program of no more than 500 lines of codes on one's own. !without the requirements are clearly explained and the required programming constructs are told!
3. Demonstrate that recursive and non-recursive functions are abstractions of sub-problems in a task.: Demonstrate thorough understanding of how recursion works. Be able to develop a recursive solution to a written problem on one's own, and sometimes contrast it with the corresponding non-recursive solution.
4. Describe the concept and the use of pointers in indirect addressing and dynamic memory allocation.: Demonstrate strong understanding of the concept of pointers. Is able to use pointers effectively in indirect addressing and dynamic memory allocation in a great variety of scenarios.
5. Demonstrate the use of several data structures.:Is able to choose the appropriate data structures such as linked lists, stacks and queues to solve problems, and implement the solution in C++ on one's own.
6. Implement an abstract data type by defining a class in an OOP language.: Given the description of a simple ADT, is able to implement it with a complete C++ class definition that includes appropriate class members and class member functions. Is able to write programs that create and manipulate ADT objects. (ADT: abstract data type)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia is a very approachable teacher who is always willing to listen to and respond to students' needs. The pace of the lectures can be quickened up during the first half while it would be better to slow down during the latter half of the lectures. (on   topics like recursion, Pointer and linked nodes)

TAs are very approachable and considerate too. I gained lots of help from them. Thanks TAs!
reviews.comment_grading:
* Many C+ in C++ is true! *

If you happen to get a mean, unfortunately many C+ in C++ class... You will probably score a C+... That is unlike to the school business school norm. Usually if you are close to/ at mean, then you can gain a B-/ B. But it seems this is another story for engineering course...

However, with a class size of 400, there was quite a number of genius students who did not only did pretty good job on nailing the course but also helped the other students on piazza.
I really appreciate them! I can see the tech talents are really rising... Thanks all who helped me on the learning journey despite the online mode.
reviews.comment_workload:
*Super heavy but worthy if you are pursuing a software engineering career*

From the perspective of a business student, the workload is super heavy... As a 4 credit course, it should be heavy, but the actual amount of work is even beyond that... Every week, apart from lecture hours, it is the best to spare 7-8 hours to revise and finish the labs. For the assignments, it is the best to spare 24 hours (accumulated) for each one if you aim to finish them near perfection. I counted my hours that I spent on this course, the hour was crazy (maybe it is because I don't really adapt to the mode of a programmer which is aka sitting in front of the computer for an afternoon/ a whole day straight every weekend.)

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Have fun fighting cheaters
reviews.comment_content:
Basic C++ content:
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue

Necessary for CS/CPEG students, and therefore as a CPEG student it was useful and I would say that it is quite interesting if you are interested in programming. If you are a year 1 student I would not suggest this course however unless you already know C++ well or VERY confident in your abilities.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rated at B, but is more of a B-.

It is commendable that Cecia does try to make the lectures interesting with some live coding sections, but in the end she ends up mostly repeating what is written on the lecture powerpoints.

Speaking of the powerpoints, they were only acceptable for learning the most basic of the concepts, if you think these can help you do the labs or the assignments, you would be wrong. Spend time learning on Youtube/Google instead. Lectures were not mandatory so its up to you if you want to attend.

Labs were OK, wait for your turn to demonstrate the code and you are done, was arranged a bit messily at first but got OK later. You could demo the code before it is your turn if you just join the Zoom meeting before the lab session.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab: 10%
Programming assignments 1: 10%
Programming assignments 2: 12%
Programming assignments 3: 16%
Quiz: 8%
Final exam: 46%

Lab: 1 per week, finish a program related to the course content that week, not to difficult to get full marks since the programs are not too complex, and you can always "ask" for help.

Quiz: Taken on a month into the semester, short refresher for things like if-else, loops and such. Averages were high. (mean: 18/24)

Programming Assignments: 3 in total, each were on a different area (recursion, pointers and such), challenging, takes a few days, however, cheating was rampant with the assignments, so averages for them were absurdly high and the department has done nothing to combat people buying code off of others, so prepared to lose a few percent of the final score if you either have integrity or are not highly skilled in C++.

Finals: 45 minute sessions, 3 sessions in total, all short questions based on reading code/writing code, this meant studying the notes were almost completely useless. This also means that if you have spent time writing code you would probably do slightly better. The exam was also formatted poorly, meaning you have to scroll up and down just to even read the question, and you have to type code in the CANVAS message box, which gives you no option to use tab to space out your code, and no other formatting options.

However none of these really mattered since the final was outrageously difficult. You are expected to finish 2 programs (about 8 functions in total) in about 35 minutes, which is absurd, mean at the end was about 40/100.

My grades:
Labs: full mark
Assignments: 9/10%, 9.5/12%, 16/16%
Quiz: 20/24
Finals: 45/100

Over all rounds up to about mean or so, and got a B, instead of a B- that I was expected, therefore grading is good in my opinion.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy.

Each lab takes a few hours to complete, especially the later ones as the later labs requires you to finish 4-5 different functions, and the difficulty gap between the lecture notes and the labs/assignments is huge, so you need to spend time learning everything yourself. Assignments usually take a few days to complete, if you are really stuck there could be a chance that someone on the piazza (discussion forum for the course) will help you.

However at the same time because you need to do so much studying just to finish the lab and assignments, if you actually did everything yourself (Hard to say for people in this course!), you would have a decent idea of everything, especially for writing code which is VERY important for the final as I have explained.

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: The first course in C++
reviews.comment_content:
1. Intro
2. Basics1, 2; Control 1, 2:
Basic syntax of C++, program control.
----Quiz----
3. Function I:
Function definition, modular programming, passing parameter (PBV and PBR)
4. Array:
1d, 2d, higher dimension arrays, array definition, initialisation, C string (special type of char[])
5. Recursion**:
The hardest topic involving logical thinking
6. Scope
7. Struct
8. Function III
9. Separate-Compilation:
Actually you have to know its application, but the code will not be examined.
10. Pointer**:
The hardest topic involving very clear concepts. lvalue and rvalue, pointers, linked list**, dynamic arrays**, memory leaks**
11. Class:
data-member, member functions, constructors and destructor, mutators and accessors
12. Stack and Queue:
Only Stack is examined this year.

I will say not all topics are new to people who can get into this course. Most of them are just different by syntax. Therefore, please do read every slide of your lecture notes. They are pretty short actually. Do recall everything covered in the quiz as they will ask you tricky questions (like those in COMP1022P). The final exam will focus more on writing codes instead of tricky questions, which is what a COMP course suppose to be :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia is very good at explaining concepts and she has good English with intonations :)

Sometimes she will make some silly mistakes, but that doesn't affect too much.

She will provide more details about labs and PAs during lessons, it will be great if you do it after watching her videos. (In this semester, we can assess all the lecture videos of the 4 sessions)

Btw, there is a piazza for everyone to post questions and everyone can reply. Better check out some questions when you got stuck in PA as many generous students are giving tips :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 8%
Lab 10%
PA 36% (10, 12 14%)
Final 46%

The quiz will examine the basic of C++. Therefore if you take 1021 before, please do more revision.

For the final exam, there are 3 parts and each part last for 45 minutes. You have to code in the Canvas textbox which TAB CANNOT BE USED and YOU HAVE TO SCROLL UP AND DOWN to copy the function prototypes :) (They banned copying)

There consists of at least one coding problem in each part and you have to understand the LONG PASSAGE and write codes. I think they do all these INTENTIONALLY to limit our time. Three tips for people taking this kind of exam later:
1. Write your code in recursive ways (usually iterative way cost more time)
2. Be sure that you can write all function taught in class without much thinking...they examine some functions like deleting linked list which already stated in the lecture notes :)
3. Mark down those important things (like prototypes, data structures...), so that you don't have to scroll up and down :D

Grade and Marks are not released...many students get ANNIHILATED by this exam ;)

----Update----
Assignment: Full
Lab: 8/9 (missing 1 lab)
Quiz: Full
Final: 78/100
Overall marks ~ 88/100
Final grade: A+

Actually I do surprised by the final grade. Since the highest of the final exam is around 92 and I am quite far from it. Better than what I expected :D
reviews.comment_workload:
No attendance for class.
1 lab every week, 3 Programming assignments, 1 quiz, 1 final

We have to finish the lab before and demo during lab session. Therefore, you have to finish it quickly and no TA can help you :( (at least for my session)

The difficulty of PA2 will be the highest since it examines the implementation of the hardest logical-demanding topic --> recursion. I know some students takes weeks to finish it. For me it takes around 20-25 hours in total.
The other 2 PA are easier, finish within 1 day.

Workload really depends on your own experience and expectations.

If you take 1021/1022q as the prerequisite, then please pay more attention because C++ is completely different from python and VBA. Especially 1021 teaches turtle??? which is useless in this course...
I think the most difficult things for 1021 students will be the syntax and concepts of OOP. (As python is too easy to use!)

If you take 1022p as the prerequisite, congrats! Those content taught in 1022p are useful in 2011(because it is also OOP). Some topics like "Class" will be easy for you :)

14. New C++ 11 features (extra)
15. C++ strings (extra)

For extra topics, they will not be covered in final exam, but they may appear in your lab and PAs.

Since comp1021/1022P/1022Q is pre-requisite, you should find it easy to follow the basics such as loop and if statement, however it will be more difficult when it comes to recursion and pointer. Class is quite straight forward after you study pointer. Pay more attention to recursion and pointer since they will be mainly focused in your final exam:)

reviews.author: Raymond Cheng
reviews.title: Very good content and teaching
reviews.comment_content:
The course teaches about the fundamentals of C++. Here is a snapshot of the syllabus:

Basics (main, namespace, data types, constants)
- Control (For loops, switch statements, enum)
- Functions (declare and call functions, pass by value & by reference, return by value & return by reference)
Struct
- Cpp11 new features (general initialization using {} list, range for statement, lambda expressions)
- Scope (File, function, block scope)
- Pointers
- Arrays
- Recursion
- Class

All of the content is very practical and up-to-date to modern C++. It helped me understand the entire syntax and how C++ works in general.

Everything starting from the basics until functions should be pretty fundamental and easy to understand if you have taken a previous CS introductory course.

Topics from Struct to Scope should be straightforward as well, just pay attention to the specific syntax and how the features are used and you should be fine.

Starting from pointers, things are getting slightly more difficult as you are expected to know how they relate to normal variables and arrays and memory manipulation. For the last few lectures, you need to know how all the concepts come together as you will be expected to implement them in the exams.

Overall the content is great and very appropriate.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is pretty articulate in explaining concepts that might be pretty difficult to understand at first. He makes things easier to comprehend and demonstrates a lot of code examples in class which will clarify a lot of things. He is also very open to any kind of questions in class, so definitely take the chance in class to ask questions you are not sure of.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is a bit harsh I would say. To my knowledge (not sure whether it is 100% accurate though), midterm mean is around 55 and final mean around 63, and you need at least 25 points above the mean to get an A. Getting the mean should be a B- or C+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is quite manageable. Every week, there will be a lab which you will have to complete a program that is already partly written for you. The labs are quite easy to complete but some, especially the later ones, might take some time.

Throughout the semester, you will also get project assignments to  do, around once per month. The assignments really demand some effort and time, so be prepared to spend more than a week on it, a few days if you have more familiarity with C++.

Fun at the beginning, quite easy and interesting, starts to get a little more difficult after midterms.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia is good, but Brian is better. Cecia goes through examples in class, which is good but tends to not cover details which we would have needed to know as she doesn't strictly follow the slides. However, brian not only goes through slides, but also goes through examples. Both are very nice professors and will help you whenever you need it.
reviews.comment_grading:
On a curve, which is kind of inconvenient for non-experienced programmers as most of the students are comfortabel with most technques taught in the class.

Quiz 5%
Labs 10%
Assignments 24%
Midterm 25%
Final 36%

Quiz is super easy, 30 min MC. Labs occur every week, can finish from before and just go to lab for 20 mins to wait your turn for demo. Asignments, trickier, you get two weeks to complete, usually provided with a skeleton code. Midterm relatively easy. Final slightly difficult. Good thing is that since grading is so spread out, everything doesn't depend on final.

Tip- Doing the self-tests on the comp 2011 course website helps a ton.
reviews.comment_workload: Somewhat heavier, as the major chunk of the grading is focused on the project based material. Lots to do during sem time. This might be inconvenient and time consuming, but at the end of the day, helps a lot with practice which is the most important part of programming. Pays of at the end.

Quiz is quite basic, just need a good understanding of C++ in general. Midterms and exams are similar to labs in the way that you have to code solutions to given problems on the fly as the exam progresses, with extra emphasis on overall content learnt in 2011 for the exams.

Labs are easy in general, each requiring no more than an hour to complete.

There are a quiz, a midterm, and a final this semester. The quiz is pretty difficult for beginners. There is a problem in final that is almost identical to PA3.

reviews.author: Uras
reviews.comment_content: I believe the course adequately teaches a lot of basic programming skills and gives you a decent understanding of beginner level C++. For someone who has started out with python, a lot of the course contents will be very new and hard to grasp. Although the course mostly tests your coding ability and not your C++ knowledge, integrating these new concepts can be quite difficult. Some topics such as functions or recursion will be familiar, but they are already a big step up from what you will learn in first year courses. So, when topics such as pointers that don't commonly exist in most other languages come into play, most people have a really hard time wrapping their heads around them. Therefore I suggest not expecting a high grade from this course if you don't have any prior experience (besides introductory python course) OR you don't intend to invest most of your time into it. As a side note, if you are intending to take this course in the future, I highly recommend taking Java first.
reviews.comment_teaching: Although Professor Brian Mak has a nice way of teaching concepts quite well, I found his pace to be very slow. This was evident by the fact that we were many lectures behind all other sections.  His speech and his tone of voice are too calm and slow which personally makes it hard to concentrate for more than 10 minutes. But besides his pacing, he is actually very interactive with the class and explains concepts nicely, although sometimes he explains the same thing too many times.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is heavily weighed towards the exams. You can expect most people to get full marks on the labs, which in my case left only the assignments and the exams. Assignments were 8% each, meaning as long as you get 90+ it shouldn't affect your grade too much. Here are my grades for reference:

Assignments (Average): 95~/100
Labs: 3/3
Midterm: 91.5/100
Final: 80.25/100
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite light overall but very compactly distributed. There are 3 long Programming Assignments, but you are given 2 weeks to complete each of them. It might sound like a long time, but with the debugging it can take several days to complete which can be hard when combined with other courses. The assignments themselves were (for me) hard to get full marks (but not hard to get good marks) on because they are quite expansive and it is hard to get past every hidden test case (i.e. your code isn't smart enough to fit every scenario).

There are also labs every week which take around 5-10 minutes to complete. Free marks.

reviews.comment_grading:
The grading itself isn't too bad for aiming B range, apparantly mean is B-. However, A range is really competitive, messing up one pa will most likely give you B range eventually(if you just score everything around A- to A).Here is my own experience.


labs 8/8 (mean 7.84?)

pa1 100/100 (mean 88.3)

pa2 100/100 (mean 84.2)

pa3 55.83/100 (mean 79.3, -1sd)

midterm 77.5/100 (mean 61.8, sd 23.5)

final 79/100 (mean 55.14, no sd is given but upper quartile is72.3 on canvas)

eventually I got B+, you can see the grading is really harsh for those aiming A range, please make sure you achieve 100s in all labs and assignments if you want an A range for sure. Considering the harsh grading for A range, I would say the grading of this course is quite bad, this is because of the ust grading policy :)
why don't ust gives more A range?? It makes me feel like all the efforts I have paid on this course were trash, nothing is meaningful

reviews.comment_grading:
10% Lab exercises
10% Quiz
37% programming assignments
43% Final exam
0% attendance

Lab x 10:
Each week has one lab, force us to practice the topic learned that week. You would have to demonstrate your work to the TAs in zoom and answer one question from the TAs in order to score full marks for each lab. The questions are usually straight forward and easy to answer so no worry. Try your best to do it by yourself, or else you need to pick up a lot of stuff to prepare for the exam.

Quiz:
35 MC questions (mean: 20.47/35)
Take place in the first few weeks. Testing the basic syntax and functions (e.g. if-else, for loops, data types ...). A lot of tricky questions. Rmb to have a good time management cause time is definitely not enough to finish the whole quiz.

Programming assignments:
Have ~20 days to finish one assignment. Suggestion: Start the assignment at least one week before the deadline. Most of the tasks are not difficult in terms of coding but takes time to sort out the logic.

Final exam:
3 parts, each part has 1 short question that asks students to find the output of a given program. Follow by a long coding question. Suggestions: Do pastpapers. You can find some pattern by looking at the answers of the pastpapers. The questions are usually 2D dynamic array, circular linked list, binominal tree, class .... Memorize the patterns/coding and you can at least get some scores even though you might not know what the question is really asking.

reviews.comment_content:
https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011

actually, looking at the course website directly yourself maybe better than reading other people's comments. (need account to log in but you should have registered one in comp 1021)(some past pages may no longer be available but you can change the year and term and find it yourself)

lab sessions need attendance. they randomize the order every time to check your lab assignment. Each TA check ~30 students and there are 2~3 TA (different sessions different number) if you are lucky to be the first one, you just need to stay for 15 minutes in the lab session. if you are the last one, you need to wait for 75 minutes in the lab session. if you fail to complete your lab, you need the whole 120 minutes.

I learned C++ for HKDSE ICT Programing. I got 5 in the end and this course is still a bit challenging for me.
Things not taught in secondary school/COMP 1021:
Separate Compilation (using multiple cpp files in one program)
Pointers (a type of variable that saves the address of another variable)
Struct (a user defined data type)
Class (a more complicated Struct with functions)
Stack and queue (they uses pointers to implement stack and queue and linked list)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cindy is a really good teacher. She explained the concepts very clearly and will answer your questions. I attended all lectures even though I enrolled in 9am lectures 🙃

The teaching team also uses Piazza, an online platform for us to ask questions. The professors/TAs/other students will answer your questions very quickly. it encourages someone as shy as me to ask questions so the whole teaching team is good.

Sometimes, she would like to chitchat with us as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading would be a bit tough, as the mean is quite high for this year, it is hard to say a guarantee A if the total mark >= 85, but you would score A if the total mark >= 90 and A+ if the total mark >= 95

Criteria:
10 Labs: 10% (1% each, get participation marks 0.3% if you show up in lab session via zoom, no zinc submission required)
3 PAs: 10%, 12%, 15%
1 Quiz: 10%
1 Final: 43%

My Score:
Lab: 10/10
Quiz: 31/35
PA: 100/100,100/100,95.x/100
Final: 93/100

My final grade was A+
reviews.comment_workload:
3 Personal Assignment
The Personal Assignments are time-consuming, it cost weeks to do the debugging, and every single error could be disaster, especially the hidden test case are very tough to deal with. Sometimes, even the TA may not get the appropriate answer at first time

10 Labs
The Labs are quite easy, usually finished each within 2 hours if you don't want to try the extra part. But it may cost days for those who are not familiar with.

1 MC Quiz
The MC Quiz is quite tricky, and we cannot modify the answer of MC during the quiz(Online Quiz in Canvas), which is pretty odd, it is easily to lose marks in that part, but lucky it only count 10%, you still can catch up if you lose too some in this part.

1 Final
The Final is fine, as many questions are come from ideas of labs, assignments and the past papers, it is recommended to revisit those parts. It would be easy to go if you are familiar with those topic very much

Overall, I think the wordload is fair if you are very interested in programming or have fundamental background of programming in C/C++, otherwise you may get into trouble while dealing with recursion, pointer and linked list as well.

Quiz: me: 17/25 (mean= 19.13, sd = 3.64)

Final: me: 33/100 (mean= 40.28, sd= 21.32, 205 students above mean)
Total:  around 65/100
Letter Grade: B-

I am not a good quick thinker, not very experienced in programming and not fully prepared for the final exam, so I did relatively poorly in exam and quiz.

Was expecting C+, but got 1 higher subgrade, I am happy about that already, as this course is hyper competitive.
reviews.comment_workload:
I guess it's reasonable for a 4 credit course. If it was a 3 cred course, I would give an E.

Nearly every week, you need to hand in a lab homework which cost you a few hours per week. And throughout the semester, you got to do 3 Programming assignments (PAs), each of which gives you about 2 weeks to work on. And then of course you have a quiz/mid-term, and a final exam. Because of COVID, the tests were all done on Canvas.

I would argue this course should be called as "Introduction to OOP and Algorithm" instead, because you always need to think of different algorithms to make your program work in labs and PAs. As someone who has nearly 0 programming background (I only took VBA 1022q before), thinking algorithms on a whim is challenging to me. It would be ideal if you can find someone to work and brainstorm together, because that's what I did to secure my PA scores.

Again, as someone who has very little programing background (I am a SBM student), the concept of recursion overwhelmed me a bit when I first learned about it, but later picked it up with the help of friendship. Surprisingly, I don't find pointer really hard, it is just confusing sometimes when you assign a lot of pointers, such as a binary tree structure, so make sure you have a crystal clear flow of thinking.

For the final, make sure you do past papers, review your past Labs and PAs, and remember how each algorithm in those questions work, because they can be very useful. However, as the exam was done on Canvas, you cannot use tab on the text editor, and for this semester, we were required to leave comments on our code, which could be very time-consuming, and causing many of us cannot finish the exam.

reviews.author: garbage

reviews.comment_workload: Actually, the workload is not that high. The labs and assignments are not hard. You can definitely make it through even if you have not learned the material before. Each PA costs you about 2-3 hours to complete most of the functions. However, if you want A range, you should pay more efforts and go through as much past papers as you can. I didn't do past papers or any additional coding problems, so I got a bad grade.

The content is very basic for beginners. However, the time arrangement is very inappropriate. Some basic features like control flow, array, recursion, etc. have been covered in COMP1022P, COMP1022Q, but they occupied half of the semester's time. However, very important and difficult parts like Pointers and Classes were taught in a short time even if 2 PAs need to applicate them and more than 50% percent credits of the final exam are related to them.

reviews.author: Yash
reviews.comment_content: The content of the course was really interesting. It will teach you the basics of c++ really well. From variables to classes and objects, the content gets interesting as the course proceeds.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture slides are detailed and very self-explanatory. They have examples for each and every concept. The code files for each example are also uploaded on the course website for assistance.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was based on assignments, labs, and the final exam. There was no midterm exam. It was replaced by an assignment. The grading is very reasonable. All appeals are catered to and inspected carefully. If marks are reduced, the reasons are given specifically. However, the course was really competitive. The online version of the final exam was graded appropriately and marks were given for steps and not just the final code.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is more than the other courses. Every week, there is a lob where you have to demonstrate the code for the task for that given lab. If you fail to do so properly, marks are deducted. So you have to be prepared before the lab each week.

The assignments consume a lot of time as well. A couple assignments took weeks to finish. There were four assignments. The third one was the hardest.

Additionally, the course content has a lot to learn. Therefore. keeping up with the lectures is important.

reviews.comment_teaching: Brian is a patient lecturer who explains concepts clearly, making clarifications whenever someone has problems. His pace of teaching could be kind of slow if you are familiar with programming. Personally I am rather new to programming considering I have only taken COMP1021 at the point when I take this course, and I find his way of teaching helpful throughout my study on the course.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is relatively harsh on this course considering there is many ambitious students who is proficient on programming taking this course. I was at the mean for most of these assignments and screwed up the last two programming assignments (got 10/100 and 60/100 respectively as I was so unfamiliar with pointers) ending up with a C.
reviews.comment_workload: Depending on how good you are at programming, the workload could be either light or extremely high for you. For normal semesters, there will be a midterm and a final examination, 10 lab exercises and 3-4 programming assignments. Take your time to revise all those concepts taught in class if you don't want to spend a whole week just for doing one single programming assignment!

reviews.author: TomNotch
reviews.title: Fundamental
reviews.comment_content: The content of COMP 2011 is easy at the beginning, as it's the basic about data type and programme flow, would be similar to Java you learnt last semester. But do not under estimate the difficulty of dynamic memory allocation, easy understanding, also easy making mistake.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is too detailed that sometimes you're gonna feel that the professor is repeating one simple concept over and over again, which could have been taught in a few words. It's too slow.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is normal, do not under estimate the difficulty of the last few assignments, as it's about dynamic memory allocation, and passing the skeleton test code doesn't mean passing the assignment to any degree, it's easy to get memory leaked even the programme runs normally at the beginning. About exam, don't over estimate it, it's actually not that difficult, but be careful about the lambda expression.
reviews.comment_workload: The first few assignments are easy so it won't take up much time, but again the last few assignments are a bit time-consuming and difficult. About lab, it's easy, don't spent too much time on it.

reviews.author: Kevin KAI
reviews.title: A little bit challenging
reviews.comment_content:
The course is a little bit difficult to follow and understand. Especially the part after pointer.
COMP1022P may just require you to know programming and how to use it. Starting from COMP2011, you should know how to develop your own logic to use the programming knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: Could explain things logically and clearly. But the voice is not clear enough. A little bit soft, so sometimes cannot totally follow what she said.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is good.
In the first quiz, I get 21/24, just around the mean of the class.
About the lab, I get full mark in every lab. Some labs are challenging than you think. Not as easy as that before.
About the Assignment, since due to those men in black, this semester we cancelled the final exam and had 4 assignment, which are count 6 marks, 8 marks, 10 marks and 10 marks respectively. The first assignment is easy and the other 3 assignments are all challenging. You need to think and spend a long time to do that.
The first assignment is about array. I only get 85/100. The mean is 86/100.
The Second assignment is about function, especially the wide use of recursion. I get 100/100. The mean is about 80 something.
The third assignment is about structure, pointer and linked list. I get 66/100 because of the memory leak. The mean is only 55/100.
The 4th assignment is about class and linked list. I get 95/100. This time I check memory leak very very carefully. The mean is 70 something.
Midterm: Midterm addressed more to test your ability about develop your own programming with your own logic. So many  long questions. I get 86/100. The mean is 70 something.
Finally, my grade is A-. Very satisfying.
reviews.comment_workload: Large workload. I think I spend 50% above time to do COMP2011 things in the whole semester.

reviews.author: Justin Li
reviews.title: Work-Intensive Programming Course
reviews.comment_content:
This courses teaches all the basics about C++ programming and gives brief introduction to OOP (Object-oriented programming). Topics include Basic if-else logics, loops, functions, arrays, recursion, struct, pointers and class. Compared to CSE introductory 1000 courses, this course is much more advanced and demanding towards logical thinking and computation. The topics before mid-term exam are considerably basic while those afterwards are much more vague and complicated, especially with recursion and  pointers which are very logical.
Lab assignments are compulsory and follows closely the contents taught in lecture. Some lab assignments, especially with recursion and pointers quite difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chung was very familiar with the content yet many will find his lectures rather tedious and boring. Those who want interesting and interactive lectures may want to choose one taught by other professors.
All labs and lab assignments are personal work and not are taught by TAs, but they were very welcoming in solving questions and clarifying concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: The expectations of this course is high. The mid-term exam was relatively easy with mean around 65%. Meanwhile, only a few students were able to receive over 75% in the final exam, mean of around 45%, and by scoring 50% will get you B range because the final exam was simply very difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Because the way of examining in this course is very different from CSE introductory courses (from filling questions and blanks to writing whole length codes), it took quite a lot of time and work to get used to the style. Revising for vague and complicated topics like recursion and pointers required completing many past exam questions. This is not an easy course, and there is no work around it, so put more time and effort to get good results.

reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor speaks in a fast-pace but understandable, which is good. However, he focused on his programming console throughout the lectures which made the class atmosphere uncomfortable for non-CS major students. I skipped most of the lectures except those having in-class quizzes because of that.

The course adopted a new syllabus which focused on students' creativity on programming, making it unideal for students who want to learn more about computer science but not programming.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Lab exercises 40% (10 total, 4% each)
Mean almost 100%
Quizzes 15% (In-class, open-book, 3 total, 5% each)
Mean: 84.1/100 (SD 19.3), 87.5/100 (SD 11.8), 74.1/100 (SD 20.0) (exclude zeros)
Final Exam 45% (Open-book)
Mean 56.2/100, SD 18.4 (exclude zeros)

The course grade was curved in a ridiculous way, I got almost full marks on labs, below mean on quizzes and below mean on final (~50%), total score was about 68-69%, final grade was a C.
A friend of mine literally scored more than half of my final exam scores (~25-30%), and he got the same grade as me (C). This is totally unfair as the final exam was the biggest deciding factor, the curve was not correlated to the final exam at all, which does not make any sense. I am actually rather disappointed and frustrated when receiving the grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are lab exercises weekly, which takes on average 4-5 hours to complete, however some labs involving pointers, linked lists are quite challenging, these would take several days to complete. So most of us have to finish the lab exercises before the lab as lab problems are posted online a week before. I personally skipped most of the lab sections and submitted the exercises on Canvas.
Quizzes are not heavy loads for me as I gave up all of them and all in final instead.
The final exam is quite challenging so it takes much time to prepare for. As I had the MATH 2033 exam one day before, there was not too much time to prepare the exam for the COMP 2011 and I suffered from it.
In all, the workload of the course is quite heavy, especially for labs involving higher-level knowledge such as pointers and linked lists.

reviews.title: Review
reviews.comment_content:
At the beginning of the course the content is very easy due to which i got exceptional score in my quiz but later the content starts getting harder.
The content are as following:
1. Pointers
2. Functions
3. Array (2D,3D)
4. Struct
5. Linked List

reviews.comment_teaching:
Our teacher was Cecilia and she tried her best to teach us. I already knew much of the concept so i cant judge much on her teaching.
For the Lab TA's, my TA was Kevin and he was very helpful. He would answer my question even via email during non office hours which helped alot.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grades are distributed as below.
1. Quiz (5%)
2. Mid term ( 25%)
3. Assignment ( 24 %)
4. Lab ( 10%)
5. Final (36%)

The quiz is during the beginning of the semester and quite easy if you have some back ground as not much has been taught.

The Mid term is like a final exam because the paper is for 2 hours and the full mark for the paper is 100. In our batch the mean was 54 which is quite low. The paper was quite tough.

The first Assignment is 5% and is quite easy. The second asssignment is 9% which is hard and the final assignment is worth 10% which is the hardest of them all.
reviews.comment_workload: The work load at the beginning of the semester is quite low but it increases exponentially. The labs get harder as you reach towards the end. The first assignment is quite easy and you will think all of them will be easy but thats not the case. The assignments get way harder later. The worst thing about the assignment is that you will have to do labs simultaneously with the assignments. If you have two weeks to do an assignment that means in those two weeks you will have to do two labs as well. As i mentioned earlier the labs get quite harder later so it consumes time as well. I think the work load is quite high for this course.
